abstract_summ: In the absence of effective vaccine or biomedical treatment, the basic rules of public health measures have not changed, namely public distancing.Even before the onset of the pandemic in Israel, fine-tuned but determined early decisions were taken by policy makers to monitor flight arrivals from Covid-19 affected regions and to limit public gatherings.We hope this paper will shed light on how insights from behavioral economics can enrich public health policies and interventions in the fight against COVID-19.Encouraging people to adopt and sustain preventive behaviors is a central focus of public health policies that seek to mitigate the spread of COVID-19.The abrupt change followed a holiday in which social distancing was clearly inefficient and many public gatherings were held.
